sense.def: a thin piece of metal with a sharp end, used to join pieces of wood together
dictionaryExamples: a three-inch nail
I stepped on a nail sticking out of a board.
Hammer a nail into the wall and we'll hang the mirror on it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes in food given to animals by visitors you can find pieces of glass, nails or even poison. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the hard surface at the end of your fingers and toes
dictionaryExamples: Stop biting your nails!
nail clippers
a nail file
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do everything for my dog, such as washing [him and], cutting his nail[s,] and I have [to] make sure he is nice and clean. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: If someone is naive, they believe things too easily and do not have enough experience of the world.
dictionaryExamples: I was much younger then, and very naive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It might sound a bit idealistic and naive, but I think this concept of communication will make the world a better place. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: not wearing clothes
dictionaryExamples: a naked man
naked bodies
He was naked to the waist.
The children were half naked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cried out in anger and that was a mistake, because the girls turned around and looked at me, standing there naked. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: A naked feeling or quality is not hidden, although it is bad.
dictionaryExamples: naked power/aggression/ambition
It is a script filled with wit and naked honesty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This program presents the naked truth about Brazil, this so called "Tropical Paradise." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If something can be seen by the naked eye, it is big enough to be seen without special equipment.
dictionaryExamples: These bugs are so tiny you cannot see them with the naked eye.

sense.def: the word or words that a person, thing or place is known by
dictionaryExamples: "Hi, what's your name?" "My name's Diane."
Please write your full  name and address on the form.
What's the name of that mountain in the distance?
That would be a good name for a dog.
The students were listed by name and by country of origin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend's name is Martin. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: the reputation that someone or something has
dictionaryExamples: She went to court to clear her name.
Their actions gave football  a bad name at the time.
They're trying to restore the good name of the manufacturer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's the only one concerned about the good name of the family. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If bad things are done in the name of something, they are done in order to help that thing succeed.
dictionaryExamples: Are you willing to work yourself to death in the name of competition?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are things one cannot trifle with: friendship for example should not be sacrificed in the name of success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to become famous or respected by a lot of people
dictionaryExamples: He's been trying to make a name for himself in the music business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, only [a] few sportsmen and sportswomen manage to make a name for themselves and get to the top. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to use impolite or unpleasant words to describe someone
dictionaryExamples: He said the other children were calling him names.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had never called me names or told me off. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
dictionaryExamples: A "suggested price" is, as the name implies, the sale price suggested by the manufacturer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sour Sweet, as the name implies, is originally a Chinese restaurant. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to give someone or something a name
dictionaryExamples: We named our dogs "Max" and "Lady."
A man named Dennis answered the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is named Maryam. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to say what something's or someone's name is
dictionaryExamples: In the first question you had to name three types of monkey.
He couldn't name his attacker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only "Tandoori dishes" but all the [dishes] are tasty, to name some there [are] Chinese, North Indian, and many others. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to choose someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Just name the time and the place and I'll be there.
Name your conditions/terms/price.
Ms Martinez has been named (as)  the new Democratic candidate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has [been]  named as the best Latin singer and he has [won] two Grammys. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that you say which means anything you say or choose
dictionaryExamples: I've never seen such a wide selection. You name it, they've got it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Courses vary from languages, management, computer-related fields to fitness, yoga, karate classes [and] all [the] different hobbies you might be interested in such as painting on silk or on wood, pottery, carving and the like. You name it, they have it at ECM. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: used when you are going to give more detail about something you have just said
dictionaryExamples: She learned an important lesson from failing that exam, namely that nothing is ever certain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This network is used by the four most used means of transport in our city (namely, bus, car, bicycle and motorcycle) and has been plagued by problems such as potholes, poor drainage and poor use (or lack!) of traffic signs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a short sleep
dictionaryExamples: He likes to take a nap after lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He usually takes a nap after lunch and at night goes to bed about 10:00 p.m. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of cloth or paper used at meals to protect your clothes and to clean your lips or fingers
dictionaryExamples: She brought paper napkins and a cake with "Happy Birthday" written on it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Tom, I received your letter and I'm going to try to answer your questions: for the wedding present, I don't think you are compelled to give them anything, but if you want to, I suggest you to offer a tablecloth and napkins, it is very useful and they will be very pleased. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a story or description of a series of events
dictionaryExamples: It's a moving narrative of wartime adventure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a happy ending, however, only because the narrative stops at this point. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the person who tells the story in a book, film, play, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The narrator is a fisherman.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Leo Colston is the narrator and chief character through whose eyes we dive into the story. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: Narrow things measure a small distance from one side to the other.
dictionaryExamples: narrow streets
a narrow bridge/doorway/path
a narrow face
narrow feet
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a charming little town with old houses and narrow streets. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: limited to a small area of interest, activity or thought
dictionaryExamples: He has narrow interests.
It was regarded as a very narrow interpretation of the law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People leave home with a narrow outlook and it doesn't seem to broaden. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If you have a narrow escape, you only just avoid danger.
dictionaryExamples: He had a narrow escape when a falling tree crushed his car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ralph will have a narrow escape: he is saved by the arrival of a ship which has at last come to rescue them all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to become less wide or to make something less wide
dictionaryExamples: The road has been narrowed to one lane.
His eyes narrowed angrily.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Driving as well as parking has become a difficult task in Copenhagen City as the City Council [has] over the last [few] years deliberately cut down the numbers of parking places, raised the fees and narrowed the roads and streets. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to become less or to make something become less
dictionaryExamples: to narrow the gap between rich and poor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tend to believe that every country should join together, as only by discussing and sorting out some measures will [we] be able to narrow the gap that nowadays exists among countries all over the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make something, for example a list or a choice, smaller and clearer by removing the things that are less important
dictionaryExamples: We've managed to narrow the list down to four.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies were narrowed down to reading books, listening to some music and that's all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: only by a small amount
dictionaryExamples: He narrowly escaped death in the accident.
She narrowly missed winning an Oscar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They narrowly escaped crash[ing] with the car in [the]opposite lane. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: not willing to accept new ideas or opinions different from your own
dictionaryExamples: I found some of my classmates to be narrow-minded.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a bit narrow-minded and at first he'll drive you crazy but once you get to know him, he'll be good company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: bad or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: a nasty shock/surprise
There's a nasty smell in here.
He had a nasty cut above the eye.
She has a nasty habit of picking on people in meetings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Inside there were three samples of a nasty purple liquid. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: unkind
dictionaryExamples: Don't be so nasty to your brother - he's four years younger than you!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I though that it was a nasty joke made by a friend, but the ad[d]ress of the sender did not match with any that I knew. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: very angry or violent
dictionaryExamples: When I asked for the money, he turned really nasty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The[n] I heard a nasty voice saying ["]Bob!["] Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a country or the people living in a country
dictionaryExamples: the industrialized nations
All the nations of the world will be represented at the conference.
Practically the whole nation watched the ceremony on television.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At that time, everyone should have devoted their life to the nation. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: relating to or typical of a whole country and its people
dictionaryExamples: a national holiday
Britain has more than ten national newspapers.
The company's national headquarters is in Rome.
The children were wearing traditional national costume/dress.
The government's view is that raising taxes now would not be in the national interest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like the music of [the] national anthem. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: If you have United States/British/Swiss, etc. nationality, you are legally a member of that country.
dictionaryExamples: She is of French nationality.
He did not give his nationality.
What nationality are you?
At the International School they have pupils of 46 different nationalities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend [was] born in Norway, but his nationality is Polish. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: existing or happening in all parts of a particular country
dictionaryExamples: a nationwide network/chain of stores
a nationwide survey
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The nationwide blackout was the first in the past decade. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in all parts of a country
dictionaryExamples: Schools nationwide are experiencing a shortage of teachers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Thursday, Friday or Saturday you could visit the annual festival, which is well-known nationwide for the music, costumes and dance of the local people. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: Your native town or country is the place where you were born.
dictionaryExamples: She returned to live and work in her native Japan.
She's a native Californian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You really tried to understand [the] far east [and] my native country, Japan. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the first language that you learn
dictionaryExamples: French is his native tongue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My native language is Russian but I speak English fluently and I have been learning Latin for two years. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: relating to the first people to live in an area
dictionaryExamples: The Aborigines are the native inhabitants of Australia.
the native people
native traditions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very happy to tell you about my trip to the Amazon forest native inhabitants museum. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: Native animals or plants live or grow naturally in a place, and have not been brought from somewhere else.
dictionaryExamples: a large bird native to North America

sense.def: someone who has spoken a particular language since they were a baby, rather than having learned it as a child or adult
dictionaryExamples: All our teachers are native speakers of English.
a native-speaker dictionary
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I mentioned, I teach English to Japanese students, [and] I'd like to spend time with native speakers to improve my English. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: Something that is natural exists or happens because of nature, not because it was made or done by people.
dictionaryExamples: natural ingredients
a natural substance
He died from natural causes.
Floods and earthquakes are natural disasters.
People say that breast-feeding is better than bottle-feeding because it's more natural.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have wonderful beaches full of natural beauty. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: normal or expected
dictionaryExamples: Of course you're upset - it's only natural.
It's natural that you should feel anxious when you first leave home.
It's quite natural to experience a few doubts just before you get married.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many people think that it is natural for famous people to be followed by journalists all the time because they are famous and everybody is curious about their [lives]. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: A natural characteristic is something you were born with.
dictionaryExamples: a natural talent
She's a natural athlete/blonde.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also my natural talent for entertaining people together with my past experience should be very useful working at [the] new theme park. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: as you would expect
dictionaryExamples: Naturally, he was very disappointed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Naturally we had to take his word for it. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: in a normal way
dictionaryExamples: Relax and try to behave naturally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result they can't behave naturally at all and become sick. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: happening or existing as part of nature and not made or done by people
dictionaryExamples: A healthy body will be able to fight off the illness naturally without the use of medicine.
He has naturally blonde hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes people say women are naturally stronger tha[n] men. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; French

sense.def: having been born with a characteristic
dictionaryExamples: naturally aggressive/funny/slim
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Clarisse McClellan is a spontane[o]us and naturally curious teenager who even enjoys simple things. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: all the plants, creatures, substances, and forces that exist in the universe, which are not made by people
dictionaryExamples: her love of nature
This new technique of artificially growing cells copies what actually happens in nature.
a nature article/book/program
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a nice place to relax and enjoy nature. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone's character
dictionaryExamples: As a child Juliana had a lovely nature - everyone liked her.
It's not really in her nature to be aggressive.
He is by nature inclined to be rather lazy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jane wasn't very suspicious by nature, but there was something weird in that. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: type
dictionaryExamples: What exactly is the nature of your business?
I don't like hunting and things of that nature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He claims that he did not improve his English because of the nature of the job. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to the navy
dictionaryExamples: a naval base/officer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is irrefutable that naval areas are in most cases abandoned by their governments. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the part of a country's armed forces which is trained to operate at sea
dictionaryExamples: My brother is an officer in the Navy.
Gabriel joined the navy in 1997.
a navy ship/vessel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Best of all, not only am I familiar [with the] life-style on a ship but I also know a lot of things about ship[s] because I was in the navy. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: very dark blue
dictionaryExamples: He was wearing a navy blue sweater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I will buy [a] navy blue carpet and black and blue furniture. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: close in distance
dictionaryExamples: Is there a train station near here?
We were near the exit.
The hotel is near the airport.
Don't come too near me - you might catch my cold.
Which bus stop is nearest (to) your house?
I moved my chair nearer to the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The park is near my house, about 10 minutes on foot. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: close in time
dictionaryExamples: He arrived near the end of the lesson.
It's nearer dawn than midnight.
We can decide which route to take nearer the time.

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean "close to being or doing something"
dictionaryExamples: The house isn't anywhere near ready.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could not have gone anywhere near 5000 miles because all our minibuses were broken down - we even stayed in one place for 8 days. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: not close in distance, time, amount or quality
dictionaryExamples: The house was nowhere near the ocean.
It's nowhere near time for us to leave yet.
I'm nowhere near finishing the book.
He's nowhere near as tall as his sister.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although people are well aware of the current situation in Switzerland, they prefer looking at other countries and comparing us to them (we are nowhere near as fat as them). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: almost in a particular state or condition
dictionaryExamples: The runners were near exhaustion.
I was near (to) tears  at one point during the movie.
This is the nearest I ever came to winning anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is strictly related to the fact that the old possess a vast amount of experience and are nearer to death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: close in distance
dictionaryExamples: I was standing just near enough to hear what they were saying.
Don't come any nearer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And they are getting nearer, I must run for my life. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: close in time
dictionaryExamples: Her birthday was getting nearer and I still hadn't bought her a present.
As the date of his operation drew near, he became more and more anxious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would appreciate very much if you could reply as soon as possible, as the school holiday is drawing near. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: close in distance
dictionaryExamples: Where's the nearest post office?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I arrived at the airport I went to the nearest [store] to buy a newspaper. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: at a time that is not far away
dictionaryExamples: Space travel may become very common in the near future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I look forward to receiving your reply in the near future. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: similar in characteristics or quality
dictionaryExamples: The nearest library is in the next town.
The park ranger said he thought this canyon in Georgia was the nearest thing to being out west for hundreds of miles.
I couldn't get any cream cheese so I bought the nearest equivalent I could find.

sense.def: not far away
dictionaryExamples: If there's a cafe nearby, we could stop for lunch.
I noticed a policeman standing nearby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can go swimming, [and] visit some of the bea[u]tiful castles nearby. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: not far away
dictionaryExamples: We stopped at a nearby store to buy some food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The nearby towns are lovely, very calm. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: almost
dictionaryExamples: It's been nearly three months since my last haircut.
I've nearly finished that book you lent me.
She's nearly as tall as her father now.
They'd eaten nearly everything before we arrived.
It was so funny - we nearly died laughing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It will be nearly two hours. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a lot less
dictionaryExamples: It's not nearly as expensive as I thought.
There are not nearly enough jobs to go round.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However this is not nearly enough, since we are restricted when it comes to us[ing] nuclear power [and] there is always a constant search for other energy sources. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: able to see clearly without glasses only things that are close up
dictionaryExamples: I've always been very nearsighted and had to get glasses in fourth grade.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't see a thing, as I'm very nearsighted. I tried to find my pair of glasses but it was so dark that I couldn't see my hand in front of me. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: organized and clean
dictionaryExamples: Your house is always so neat - how do you manage it with three children?
She likes everything neat and well organized.
You've got such neat handwriting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always go to this restaurant because it's neat and clean. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: very good, fun, nice, or interesting
dictionaryExamples: That video game is really neat!
Kyle has the neatest mom - she lets him stay up late on the weekends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Have you seen Marian recently? Does she still going out with Robert?  What a neat couple they were.First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in a clean and organized way
dictionaryExamples: neatly dressed
a neatly folded pile of clothes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The performers are all neatly dressed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used in negatives to mean "in every case" or "therefore"
dictionaryExamples: That's not necessarily true.
The fact that something is cheap doesn't necessarily mean it's of low quality.
You may love someone without necessarily wanting to marry them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important point in a job interview is to give a good impression, which does not necessarily mean how you look. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: needed in order to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: If necessary, we can change the dates of our trip.
We don't want to take any more luggage with us than is necessary.
I won't stay any longer than necessary.
He lacks the necessary skills for the job.
Is it necessary to give so much detail?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For me, it's necessary to be modern and cool, fashionable too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the need for something
dictionaryExamples: There's no financial necessity for her to work.
Sewing is something I do out of necessity, not for pleasure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, the most important lesson to learn is to acknowledge the necessity of education and the str[uggle] to make it happen. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: something you need
dictionaryExamples: Most people seem to consider a car a necessity, not a luxury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With development came gas-guzzling cars and motorbikes.  These have become a necessity in our everyday lives. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: the part of the body which joins the head to the shoulders
dictionaryExamples: He had the thickest neck I'd ever seen.
She wore a gold chain around her neck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was really shocked when I noticed it wasn't on my neck. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

blocks.phrase: be a pain in the neck

sense.def: to be annoying
dictionaryExamples: My brother can be a real pain in the neck sometimes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's adorable although sometimes he can really be a pain in the neck (don't tell him I wrote this.) Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: the part of a piece of clothing that goes around your neck
dictionaryExamples: a V-neck sweater
His shirt was open at the neck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pomona was so pretty, with her short blue and white dress, her bow on the neck and her hat. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If two people who are competing are neck and neck, they are very close and either of them could win.
dictionaryExamples: The two runners were neck and neck coming into the last lap.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was [a] really neck and neck match that took my breath away every second. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a piece of jewelry that you wear around your neck
dictionaryExamples: a gold/silver necklace
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Elaine, The party was wonderful and I got the necklace which I wanted so much. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a long, thin tie worn around the neck, under a shirt collar
dictionaryExamples: He wore a gray suit, with a white shirt, black and gray necktie, and silver cuff links.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also many men frequent stores in order to buy better clothing, suits, shoes, neckties, to have a better presentation at the places were they go with frequency or for busines[s]. International English Language Testing System; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If you need something, you must have it.
dictionaryExamples: I need some new shoes.
Babies need constant care.
He needs an operation.
I need you to help me choose an outfit.
I badly need  a break from all this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you need help, everyone give[s] you help. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: If you need to do something, it is necessary to do it.
dictionaryExamples: I need to do some shopping on my way home from work.
I need to go to the bathroom.
Do we need to go with her?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to l[earn] Engl[i]sh. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Farsi

blocks.phrase: don't need to do sth/needn't do sth

sense.def: used in order to say that someone does not have to do something or should not do something
dictionaryExamples: I can get there myself so you don't need to take me.
You needn't bring any food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You don't need to bring anything, but if you want, you can bring some pencil[s]. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: If something needs something to be done to it, that thing should be done in order to improve it.
dictionaryExamples: The car needs to be serviced.
This room needs brightening up a bit.
She needs to wash her hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is so beautiful but it needs washing all the time. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to say that something is necessary
dictionaryExamples: There needs to be more funding for education in this country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, there needs to be a proper choice of subjects taught, because what we should get in the end is a versatile person, not just some math or literature freak who is not interested in anything else. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: something that is necessary to have or do
dictionaryExamples: There's a growing need for affordable housing in the larger cities.
Is there any need to change the current system?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I beli[e]ve that human beings will always have the need for knowledge and entertainment at the same time. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If there is no need to do something or no need for something, it is not necessary or it is wrong.
dictionaryExamples: There's no need to go to the store - there's plenty of food in the refrigerator.
I understand why she was angry but there was no need for that kind of language.
There's no need to shout, for goodness' sake! Just calm down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me that I could trust him with the ticket and that there was no need for me to take it home. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to need something
dictionaryExamples: My car's in desperate need of repair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is also constantly in need of money. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the things you need in order to have a good life
dictionaryExamples: her emotional needs
The city is struggling to meet the needs of  its homeless people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love swimming and cycling and that is why I want to ask if there are any facilities that could suit my needs? First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: if it is necessary
dictionaryExamples:
If need
 be, we can take two cars.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: On the one hand I won't indulge my children's whims and I will lecture them or punish them if need be. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a thin, pointed metal object with a small hole at one end for thread, used in sewing
dictionaryExamples: a needle and thread
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was impossible for me to open the door, it was like [thread]ing a needle with gloves [on]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the thin, sharp, metal part of a piece of medical equipment used to take blood out of the body or to put a liquid or medicine in
dictionaryExamples: He fainted at the sight of the needle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, for all the side effects they may have, for all the unpleas[a]ntness of having a needle stuck in your arm or a spoonful of foul-tasting liquid stuck in your mouth, antibiotics and vaccines remain the greatest discovery in the history of the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to push thread through the hole in a needle
dictionaryExamples: Could you thread this needle for me, please?

sense.def: A negative sentence or phrase is one which contains a word such as "not," 'no," "never" or "nothing."
dictionaryExamples: "I've never seen him in my life" is a negative sentence.
"Don't" and "do not" are negative forms of "do."

sense.def: not having enthusiasm or positive opinions about something
dictionaryExamples:
negative
 feelings
Many people have a negative attitude toward aging.
You're so negative about everything!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the same time there were no negative opinions about the service from the visitors [to] "Fine food". First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: A negative effect is bad and causes damage to something.
dictionaryExamples: Transportation problems have had a very negative effect/impact on tourism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if it provides a lot of advantages, this revolution in the world of communication [also] has a negative impact on our society. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: expressing the answer no
dictionaryExamples: We received a negative answer to our request.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Museums are the best example to show how life was in the past but when you ask teenagers [whether] they have been  in a museum you will get a negative answer. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: with a bad effect
dictionaryExamples: They were very negatively affected by the changes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We neither walk nor do exercises and it influences our health negatively. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to not give enough care or attention to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: to neglect your appearance
She had neglected the program and allowed student interest in it to fall off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So people, use what technology has to offer you but don't neglect the person next to you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to not do something, often intentionally
dictionaryExamples: He neglected to mention the fact that we could lose money on the deal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our colleagues at the museum apparently neglected to notify us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: when you do not give enough care or attention to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: to suffer years of neglect
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, concerning the [bus]es, all I can say is that they were in a complete state of neglect. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: when you are not careful enough in something you do, especially in a job where your actions affect other people
dictionaryExamples: Her parents plan to sue the surgeon for medical negligence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite this situation of state negligence, bad laws and scarce funding, sports have managed to survive the harsh years of transition and most importantly people have not lost their interest in sports. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: not giving enough care or attention to a job or activity, especially where your actions affect someone else
dictionaryExamples: The report found him negligent in his duties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to the research, a lot of people find it more difficult to go back to work after [the] holidays and tend to be more lax and negligent at work for the first few days. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: small and not important
dictionaryExamples: a negligible effect/result
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The damage that the developing world is causing to the environment is almost negligible compared to the damage caused by the industrialised world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to try to make or change an agreement by discussion
dictionaryExamples: to negotiate with employers about working conditions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should also negotiate the best terms for our client. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when people try to make or change an agreement by discussion
dictionaryExamples: Peace negotiations are due to start.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, I would like to propose a meeting that can be arranged [in] the next week so that we may continue this negotiation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who lives very near you, especially in the next house
dictionaryExamples: Some of the neighbors complained about the noise from our party.
Have you met Pat, my next-door neighbor?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I though[t] that someone stole my ball. I think [it] was my neighbor. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: someone or something that is near or next to someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: The French make more films than some of their European neighbors.
Take 5 minutes to discuss this with your neighbor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [M]y freedom should stop where the freedom of my neighbor be[gins]. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an area of a town or city that people live in
dictionaryExamples: There were lots of kids in my neighborhood when I was growing up.
This is a good neighborhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And then I saw Sibylle, a girl who lived in my neighborhood a few years ago. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: near or next to somewhere
dictionaryExamples: neighboring countries/states
She married a man from a neighboring town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is incredible that my son ha[s] to commute to the neighboring town just to get a few books to read. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to say that a negative fact is also true of someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Jerry doesn't like it, and neither do I.
Her family wouldn't help her and neither would anyone else.
She's not very tall and neither is her husband.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, she never thought those would be the lucky numbers and neither did her husband, so he forgot to ask her about the ticket later. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not either of two people or things
dictionaryExamples: Luckily, neither child was hurt in the accident.
Neither of us had ever been to London before.
They gave us two keys, but neither worked.
"Which one would you choose?" "Neither."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Three years ago, when I was in Japan, my parents were both working and neither of them were at home by the time I g[o]t back from school. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: used when a negative fact is true of two people or things or when someone or something does not have either of two qualities
dictionaryExamples: Neither he nor his mother would talk to the police.
Their performance was neither entertaining nor educational.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have neither climbed nor surfed before, so that would be very exciting for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a son of your sister or brother, or a son of the sister or brother of your husband or wife
dictionaryExamples: My nephew is 21 today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went with my husband, my two sisters and some nieces and nephews. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the state of being nervous
dictionaryExamples: I always suffer from nerves before a game.
I need something to calm my nerves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to calm my nerves. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the ability to be calm in difficult situations
dictionaryExamples: You need a cool head and steady nerves for this job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know very well you have steady nerves but what is strong can become weak as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to annoy someone, especially by doing something again and again
dictionaryExamples: If we spend too much time together, we end up getting on each other's nerves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I would definitely avoid driving (which would soon get on my nerves) and choose to go by bicycle, singing in the sun and in the rain. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: worried or anxious
dictionaryExamples: He gets very nervous before exams.
I was too nervous to speak.
I was very nervous about driving again after the accident.
She's always been nervous around dogs.
a nervous cough/laugh
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm a little nervous because of that. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: in a worried and anxious way
dictionaryExamples: to giggle/laugh nervously
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As always the girls sat down in the fifth row and waited nervously for the event to begin. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: the state of being nervous
dictionaryExamples: Her nervousness was obvious when she spoke.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember, by and large, failures are sparked off by nervousness. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: a home built by birds for their eggs and by some other creatures to live in
dictionaryExamples: a birds'/wasps' nest
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The very rare 'Cove Owl' has chosen one of the empty tree trunks by the pond to build his nest. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a sum of money that has been saved or kept for a specific purpose
dictionaryExamples: She used her nest egg to buy a really good  piano.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was the only heir of a rich family and her husband, who died ten years ago, le[f]t her a sizeable nest egg. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to live in a nest or build a nest
dictionaryExamples: There are birds nesting under the roof.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you stroll along the path on a Sunday morning, you can see robins nesting in the old honeysuckle bush. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a system or group of connected parts
dictionaryExamples: a road/rail network
A television network is looking into the story.
The company plans to upgrade its phone network.
We could reduce our costs by developing a more efficient distribution network.
a network of spies/a spy network
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Switzerland is a safe, small and beautiful country [that is] perfect to travel [in], because of the best publi[c] transport[ation] network in the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a set of computers that are connected to each other
dictionaryExamples: All our offices are on the same network.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, with [a] computer network, it can be possible [for] people [to] work from home, making projects, control[l]ing operations or having conferences. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the activity of meeting and contacting people who might be useful to know, especially for your job
dictionaryExamples: Students find networking essential to finding the right job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure there are many other benefits working can bring to us, apart from the enjoyment, networking, etc. that I have mentioned above, and of course the money it makes.  International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: independent and not supporting any side in an argument, fight, or competition
dictionaryExamples: neutral ground/territory
He decided to remain/stay neutral on the issue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, its main advantage is that the information you get is not provided by a company or something like that but by a neutral person. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: Neutral colors are not strong or bright.
dictionaryExamples: Try neutral creams and grays.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Throughout the house the carpets are brand new and lovely neutral colors. International English Language Testing System; C1; Afrikaans

sense.def: not ever, not one time
dictionaryExamples: We've never been to Australia.
I've never heard anything so ridiculous.
Let us never forget those who gave their lives for their country.
Wars never solve anything.
He threatened to shoot, but I never thought  he would.
It's never too late to start eating a healthy diet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never have enough time [to do] it. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to tell someone not to worry about something because it is not important
dictionaryExamples: "I'm afraid I've lost that wallet you gave me." "Well, never mind, I can easily buy you another one."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Never mind Ally, forget it, I know you['ve] been busy. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used to emphasize something negative
dictionaryExamples: I never knew you lived around here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never knew what happened after I left. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If something is never-ending, it continues for ever.
dictionaryExamples: The housework in this place is just never-ending.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are often forced to study till about thirty years of age, and it really appears to be [a] never-ending story. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: despite that
dictionaryExamples: I knew a lot about the subject already, but her talk was interesting nevertheless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both the options you gave seem very interesting. Nevertheless, I get the impression that working with animals is much more fun, don't you think? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: recently made or having started to exist recently
dictionaryExamples: a new car
She's very creative and always coming up with new ideas.
What's new in the fashion world?
We have to invest in new technology if we are to remain competitive.
It was a new bike - she never buys anything second-hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We spok[e] [a]bout new clothes and new fashion. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not  known or discovered before
dictionaryExamples: I love learning new languages.
I learned a new word today.
This new cancer treatment offers hope to many sufferers.
New evidence has since emerged.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every day at college I learn new words and new things in my life. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: different from before
dictionaryExamples: I met Janet's new boyfriend.
She's looking for a new job.
Have you seen Anna's new house?
a new generation of software
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In [the] disco I can meet more new people. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not yet familiar or experienced
dictionaryExamples: I'm new to the area.
She's new to the job so you can't expect her to know everything yet.
New staff are given training.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I met a guy called Marc [who] is pretty cool. He is also new to the club. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: new people in an organization who will provide new ideas and energy
dictionaryExamples: We need some new blood in the organization.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Regardless of the age limit many companies encourage employees in high positions to retire after 55 as they want some new blood or probably a new look for the company. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to start to behave in a better way
dictionaryExamples: I turned over a new leaf and began getting to work on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She promised to turn over a new leaf. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: recently
dictionaryExamples: the newly formed neighborhood association
Newly-discovered documents cast doubt on the guilt of the two men.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ricardo has newly arrived here from Argentina. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: new information
dictionaryExamples: I've got some good/bad news for you.
That's the best news I've heard for a long time!
Have you heard the news about Tina? She's leaving.
We just heard the good news – congratulations on your promotion!
Why don’t you call them and see if there’s any news?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Write soon, I'm waiting for good news from you too! Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: the announcement of important events on television, radio, and in newspapers
dictionaryExamples: It was on the 6 o'clock news.
the nightly news
I usually listen to/watch the 11 o'clock news.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It'll be shown next Thursday, just after the news. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to affect someone badly/well
dictionaryExamples: This weather is bad news for farmers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Focusing now on Kavanagh Catering Services, it could be said that for them price is [the] main variable - obviously this [is] good news for students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to be a surprise to someone
dictionaryExamples: He's leaving? Really? That's news to me.

sense.def: to tell someone about something new or important
dictionaryExamples: When they broke the news of their engagement, their parents were was delighted.
Who's going to break the news to his wife?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't hard to understand why she was filled with delight and happiness when her manager broke the news. The company was opening a new branch in Miami and they wanted her to become the director there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a regular report with information for people who belong to an organization or who are interested in a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: a monthly newsletter about business and the environment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And if you decide to use our newsletter service, you'll always be up-to-date. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: large, folded sheets of paper which are printed with the news and sold every day or every week
dictionaryExamples: She never reads a newspaper.
a daily/Sunday newspaper
a local/national newspaper
I read about it in the newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  He get[s] up every day [at] 6 o'clock, ha[s] breakfast and read[s] the newspaper. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: paper from newspapers
dictionaryExamples: You'd better wrap that mirror up in newspaper before you put it in the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You [should] wear your old clothes and please [bring] some old newspaper. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: in the next room, house, or building
dictionaryExamples: What are your next-door neighbors like?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We visited the same boarding school and have been classmates since Grade 7. The last two years, she was my next door neighbor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: in the next room, house, or building
dictionaryExamples: That's the old man who lives next door to Paul.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maria didn't understand, but then she realized that the man she was looking for lived next door. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: very close to something or someone, with nothing in between
dictionaryExamples: Come and sit next to me.
The factory is right next to a residential area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left it in your bedroom, next to your desk. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: pleasant or attractive
dictionaryExamples: Did you have a nice holiday?
They live in a nice house.
Have a nice day/time!
Thanks for calling - it's been nice talking to you.
You look nice in that dress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But you can make me a nice dinner. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: kind and friendly
dictionaryExamples: He's a really nice guy.
She seemed very nice.
She was very nice to me.
It was very nice of her to drive you home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  My teacher is very nice. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish

sense.def: used to emphasize a positive quality
dictionaryExamples: nice and clean
This chair's nice and comfy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, I think I'm in a good class and also my home is nice and comfortable. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: well
dictionaryExamples: That table would fit nicely in the bedroom.
His business is doing very nicely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a pleasant, easy book with useful, active vocabulary and short, nicely constructed sentences. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in a pleasant way
dictionaryExamples: She's always very nicely dressed.
If you ask your dad nicely, he might drive you there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the rooms are big, clean and nicely decorated. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a name used informally instead of your real name
dictionaryExamples: Do you have a nickname?
Angel is his nickname for her.
He is very big so that's how he earned the nickname "tiny."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I heard about [the club] [from] a friend, so I join[ed] it immediat[e]ly (I like science fiction films a lot) and I took a strange member "card": in fact it is a blue sphere with my name, my nickname ("The Sleeping Dragon") and my favorite character's image from the film (Neo) on it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a name used informally instead of your real name
dictionaryExamples: Sonny is his nickname - his real name is Joseph.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In school I had the nickname the Joker, because I had the abil[i]ty to make other people la[ugh]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a daughter of your brother or sister, or a daughter of your husband's or wife's brother or sister
dictionaryExamples: We're taking my niece on vacation with us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bought a purple sweater and I want to knit one like mine for my niece. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the time in every 24 hours when it is dark and people usually sleep
dictionaryExamples: It gets cold at night.
I slept really badly last night.
I spent the night at Ted's.
He took the night ferry/train.
The phone rang in the middle of the night.
They're open from 7 in the morning until 10 o'clock at night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cracov is [an] interesing place and look[s] nice at night. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: the period from the evening to the time when you go to sleep
dictionaryExamples: We're seeing them on Saturday night.
I've been out every night this week.
Did you have a good time last night?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go to the disco and dance all night. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a night when you are not able to sleep
dictionaryExamples: He'd spent a sleepless night worrying about his exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the rooms we stayed in did not have air-condition[ing], which caused many sleepless nights to the majority of us due to the intense heat. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a place where you can dance and drink at night
dictionaryExamples: We had a meal and then went to a nightclub.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We asked them if they wanted to come with [us] to a new nightclub, they agreed and we went to Club Pasha. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: entertainment for the night such as bars, clubs, restaurants, and theaters
dictionaryExamples: What's the nightlife like around here?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The nightlife in my country is wonderful! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a very unpleasant experience
dictionaryExamples: Being trapped underwater is my worst nightmare.
The whole journey was a nightmare - we lost our luggage and we arrived two days late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I must buy something, I usually can't find it and then shopping become[s] a nightmare. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a frightening dream
dictionaryExamples: a terrifying nightmare
I shouldn't have watched that movie - it'll give me nightmares.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every night I had a nightmare. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: the number 9
dictionaryExamples: a nine-month prison sentence
The birthday girl was wearing a badge with a nine on it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I start college at half past nine. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Romanian

sense.def: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionaryExamples: When I heard I got the job, I was on cloud nine!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes," she was on cloud nine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the number 19
dictionaryExamples: eighteen, nineteen, twenty
Her daughter is nineteen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [had a] birthday [party] in my house when I [became] nineteen. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: the number 90
dictionaryExamples: eighty, ninety, a hundred
Ninety percent of the people surveyed were in favor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Friday is the art class day.  It is [in] ninety minutes. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to be aged between 90 and 99
dictionaryExamples: He is in his nineties now.

sense.def: the years 1990 through 1999
dictionaryExamples: I spent most of the nineties traveling around the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another aspect which shows us the danger that the car represents to human life in the nineties [is] pollution. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: 9th written as a word
dictionaryExamples: The ninth letter of the alphabet is I.
The school year ends on the fourth of June.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My free day is Tuesday the ninth of December. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: something that you say in order to disagree, give a negative answer, or say that something is not true
dictionaryExamples: "You told me." "No, I didn't!"
"Can I have another chocolate?" "No, you've had enough."
"Do you like him?" "No."
"Did you get some bread?" "No, sorry, I forgot."
"Have you got any homework tonight?" "No."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in the office last week, but she said: "No!" Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: something that you say to agree with something that is negative
dictionaryExamples: "He's not very bright, is he?" "No, I'm afraid not."

sense.def: used to refuse an offer politely
dictionaryExamples: "Would you like a drink?" "No thanks, I've just had one."

sense.def: something that you say when you are shocked and upset
dictionaryExamples: Oh no! It's gone all over the carpet!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oh no! Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: not any
dictionaryExamples: The work should be done no later than Friday.
There were no more than fifteen people at the concert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In no more than ten lines, my mother explained that she was moving to Brazilia, the capital of our country, and that she would take me and my brother with her. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: not any
dictionaryExamples: There's no butter left.
There are no pockets in these pants.
That's my kind of holiday - no telephone, no computer and no worries.
There's no chance  of us getting there by eight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Ally, that's no problem about the party. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used in signs and on notices to show that something is not allowed
dictionaryExamples: No smoking/fishing

sense.def: something that you say to mean you can or will do what someone has asked you to do
dictionaryExamples: "Can you get me to the airport by 11.30?" "No problem."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jo, No problem. I can help you. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: something that you say when someone has thanked you for something
dictionaryExamples: "Thanks for taking me home." - "No problem."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's ok, no problem. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to tell someone that something is impossible
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry but there's no way we can help you.
No way will she agree to you leaving early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't worry, there is no way I'm going to miss it! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: it is not surprising
dictionaryExamples: No wonder the children are excited - this is the first time they've been abroad.
"If brutal killers like these two are at work, it is no wonder that so many people have fled," he said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No wonder that people are more tired and are not interested in reading books as much as in the past. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: If there is no need to do something or no need for something, it is not necessary or it is wrong.
dictionaryExamples: There's no need to go to the store - there's plenty of food in the refridgerator.
I understand why she was angry but there was no need for that kind of language.
There's no need to shout, for goodness' sake! Just calm down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me that I could trust him with the ticket and that there was no need for me to take it home. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrase: be no good or be not any/much good

sense.def: to not be useful, helpful or valuable
dictionaryExamples: Boots are no good if they aren't waterproof.
Food aid isn't much good until the fighting stops.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When [it] is raining, you get wet and that's no good to anyone. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to emphasize that something does not exist
dictionaryExamples: There's no such thing as ghosts!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when I asked for these, I was told that no such thing existed and so the advertisement was once again proved wrong. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used to emphasize that something cannot be changed
dictionaryExamples: I never manage to lose any weight, no matter how hard I try.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No matter where you are [or] what you do, appar[e]ntly you need electricity. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: used to say that something is very likely
dictionaryExamples: No doubt she'll spend the money on new clothes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No doubt I will find the skills acquired [during] the course, especially speaking skills, most useful in my future contacts with clients from English-speaking countries. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: none at all
dictionaryExamples: There's no evidence whatsoever that she was involved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, the hotel we were finally dumped in was situated miles from Edinburgh city cent[e]r and there was no entertainment whatsoever arranged for the evening, even though all the travelers were more or less stuck there. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: honest, brave, and kind
dictionaryExamples: a noble gesture
He was a generous, noble man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Charity is a very noble way of spending your money and it is defin[i]tely a way in which you would want to be remembered. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: belonging to the highest social group of a society
dictionaryExamples: She was born into an ancient, noble family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Capodistrias, coming from a noble family of the Ionian islands played, as a diplomat and mainly as Russia's Foreign Minister, an important role to the new European structure after the destr[uction] of Napoleon's Empire (1814). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: no person
dictionaryExamples: Nobody called.
Nobody agreed with me.
There was nobody there I could ask.
Sally helped me but nobody else bothered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was a pool but nobody went in because it was too cold. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to move your head up and down as a way of agreeing, to give someone a sign, or to point to something
dictionaryExamples: Many people in the audience nodded in agreement.
When I suggested a walk, Elena nodded enthusiastically.
She looked up and nodded for me to come in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She approached him calmly, showing no signs of nervous[ness] or uncertainty. "Do you have it?" He nodded and shoved his hand into the left pocket of his jacket. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a sound, often a loud, unpleasant sound
dictionaryExamples: The noise out in the street was deafening.
Stop making so much noise!
The engine was making funny noises.
I heard a loud noise and ran to the window.
traffic/background noise
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In college I don't like to[o] m[uch] noise. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Albanian

sense.def: making a lot of noise
dictionaryExamples: a noisy crowd of fans
noisy neighbors
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't [remember] who was there... [it] was very busy and noisy! Key English Test; A2; Polish

sense.def: to officially suggest a person for a job or a position in an organization, or to suggest a person or their work for a prize
dictionaryExamples: Judges are nominated by the governor.
The film was nominated for an Academy Award.
He was nominated as best actor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being an Ambassador for Youth bears [a] lot of responsibility, not only because the person must be [of] outstanding character and well-known, but also because they must behave accordingly and be able to convey a positive message. After deep consideration, I have decided to nominate Jovanotti, alias Lorenzo Cherubini. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: the act of officially suggesting a person for a job or their work for a prize
dictionaryExamples: to seek/win a nomination
He won the Democratic nomination for mayor of Chicago.
She has just received her fourth Oscar nomination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please allow me to support this nomination by pointing out some facts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not any
dictionaryExamples: None of us smoke(s).
None of my children has/have blond hair.
"I'd like some more cheese." "I'm sorry there's none left".
"Have you any idea how much this cost?" "None at all/None whatsoever."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since none of us had been there before we hired a guide who claimed that he knew English and then we began looking at the ruins. Preliminary English Test; B1; Danish

sense.def: If something is none of someone's business, they do not need to know about it, although they want to, because it does not affect them.
dictionaryExamples: I'm certainly not going to tell Lara how much money I've spent - it's none of her business!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You might think it's none of my business, but I simply have to say this. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: not at all clean/clever/pleased, etc.
dictionaryExamples: His clothes were none too clean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, without further ado I accepted, although I was none too sure of what was going to happen there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: not any happier/poorer/wiser, etc., than before
dictionaryExamples: She must have explained the theory three times, but I'm still none the wiser.

sense.def: despite what has just been said
dictionaryExamples: He was extremely rude in meetings. Nonetheless, his arguments found some support.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nonetheless, all the people from whom I have received letters are satisfied, as well as their children, who enjoyed the stories and the pony rides very much. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not existing
dictionaryExamples: Crime is virtually nonexistent around here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The country's economy is nonexistent, its main source of income being black market distribution of the foreign aid and gradual confiscation of the property of the few foreign companies left in the country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something someone has said or written is nonsense, it is silly and not true.
dictionaryExamples: She talks such nonsense sometimes.
He dismissed the accusations as complete/utter nonsense.
What a load of nonsense!
It's nonsense to suggest that they could have cheated.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I feel totally disappointed and I would like my money back, because everything [i]n the advertisement was nonsense. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: describes a place where people are not allowed to smoke
dictionaryExamples: Let's get a table in the non-smoking area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can also choose between a smoking and a non-smoking area. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: 12 o'clock in the middle of the day
dictionaryExamples: He has until noon to act.
The service will be held at 12 noon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll start at 12 noon and remember to wear an apron. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: no person
dictionaryExamples: No one told me she was sick.
There was no one there.
"Who was there?" "No one you would know."
I'd like to go to the concert but no one else  wants to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to come but my mother is sick and no one else can look after her. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; German

sense.def: usual, ordinary, and expected
dictionaryExamples: a normal working day
Lively behavior is normal for a four-year-old child.
It's normal to argue with your partner now and then.
They were selling the goods at half the normal cost.
The temperature was above/below normal for the time of year.
Now that everyone's back from their vacations, things are back to normal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will wear normal and comfortable clothes while painting. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: to go back to the usual condition
dictionaryExamples: Life has begun to return to normal now that the holidays are over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After exactly ten minutes the electricity was switched on again and our life returned to normal - what a relief! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a situation in which everything is happening normally
dictionaryExamples: a return to normality
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We become self-oriented and disregard those unable to fit in our perception of normality. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: usually
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't normally arrive until ten.
Normally, I plan one or two days ahead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I normally order fried fish. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in the ordinary way that you would expect
dictionaryExamples: Both lungs are now functioning normally.
She's behaving perfectly normally for a two-year-old.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the truth is that those animals are not beh[a]ving normally. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the direction that is on your left when you face toward the rising sun
dictionaryExamples: The points of the compass are North, South, East and West.
The stadium is to the north of the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can get there going on the road [to] the north of my town. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the part of an area that is further towards the north than the rest
dictionaryExamples: They live in the north of the country.
Most of the country will be dry tomorrow, but the north will have some rain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm in Santander, in the north of Spain. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in or forming the north part of something
dictionaryExamples: North America/Africa
the north coast of Iceland
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was about a team who went to visit North America. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: toward the  north
dictionaryExamples: The road leads north.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From that beach, we continued north and visited other small beaches. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the direction which is between north and east or the northeast part of a country
dictionaryExamples: They live in the northeast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The owner is from the northeast of China. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: in the northeast, or facing toward the northeast
dictionaryExamples: I don't really know the northeast part of the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should visit the Northeast Region which is famous for its white sandy beaches which are fringed with coconut trees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in or from the north part of an area
dictionaryExamples: northern Europe
the Northern Hemisphere
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last Summer I went to Chiang Mai, in northern Thailand with my family. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: the direction which is between north and west or the northwest part of a country
dictionaryExamples: The wind is coming from the northwest.

sense.def: in the northwest, or facing toward the northwest
dictionaryExamples: We climbed the northwest face of the mountain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My cousin lives in [the] northwest part [of] London and so I took [the] underground to central London every day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: the part of your face through which you breathe and smell
dictionaryExamples: a big nose
I've got a sore throat and a runny nose.
Come on now, stop crying and blow your nose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has a small nose, two big eyes, and wears a dress. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to show too much interest in a situation that does not involve you
dictionaryExamples: You shouldn't go sticking your nose into other people's business!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John started poking his nose into her life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

blocks.phrase: turn your nose up at sth

sense.def: to not accept something because you do not think it is good enough for you
dictionaryExamples: She turned up her nose at the job because she didn’t think it had enough status.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, she will not turn her nose up at anybody who might be considered less worthy than her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If something bad happens under your nose, it happens close to you but you do not notice it.
dictionaryExamples: They were stealing money from under my nose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will be surprised that there was something right under your nose that you could not live without. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a feeling of happiness mixed with sadness when you think about things that happened in the past
dictionaryExamples: his nostalgia for his college days
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He combines the strings with the brass instruments in a way that creates the feeling of nostalgia; nostalgia for the days and time I used to spend with my father. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: feeling both happy and sad when you think about things that happened in the past
dictionaryExamples: Talking about those holidays has made me feel quite nostalgic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While listening to what people interviewed were saying, I couldn't help feeling a bit sad in a nostalgic way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: one of the two holes at the end of your nose
dictionaryExamples: Breathe in through one nostril.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When he finally reached the house and managed to open the door, a musty stench assaulted his nostrils. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: always trying to find out private things about other people
dictionaryExamples: I was a nosy kid.
Don't be so nosy!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was known [as] being a nosy and m[y]sterious lady. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: used to form a negative phrase after verbs like "be," "can," "have," "'will," "must," etc., usually used in the short form "n't" in speech
dictionaryExamples: He's not fat!
I won't tell her.
I can't go.
Don't you like her?
It isn't difficult.
I'm just not interested.
He's not bad-looking!
He's not as tall as his father.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's not a problem for me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: used to give the next word or group of words a negative meaning
dictionaryExamples: I told you not to do that.
I like most vegetables but not cabbage.
"Come and play football, Dad." "Not now, Jamie."
It was Yuko who said that, not Richard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I go to college [but] not every day. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Cantonese

sense.def: used after verbs like "be afraid," "hope," "suspect," etc. in short, negative replies
dictionaryExamples: "Is he coming with us?" "I hope not."
"Have you finished?" "I'm afraid not."

sense.def: used to express the possibility that something might not happen
dictionaryExamples: Are you going to reply or not?
I still don't know whether she's coming or not.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Are [you] busy or not that day? Key English Test; A2; Singhalese
