sense.def: used to say what the situation will be if something does not happen
dictionaryExamples: I hope to see you there but, if not, I'll call you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to paint my bedroom with the pink paint. Remember to put on your old cloth[e]s. If not, your clothes will become pinky and you can't use them anymore. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: used before adjectives and adverbs to mean "not very"
dictionaryExamples: "How was your exam?" "Not too bad, I suppose."
I didn't play too well today.
He wasn't too happy when I told him about the mistake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How are you? [I'm] not too bad. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: satisfactory
dictionaryExamples: That's not bad for such a small company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The presents are not bad. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: used to form questions when you think the answer will be "yes," using the short form "n't"
dictionaryExamples: She's very pretty, isn't she?
You like cheese, don't you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know that you love horror movies, don't you? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used as a polite reply after someone has thanked you
dictionaryExamples: "Thanks for helping." "Not at all."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: ["]Thank you.["] ["]Not at all[."] Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that something is true although it seems surprising
dictionaryExamples: He even remembered my birthday, believe it or not.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First I visited the "Roman Bath'' which is more than 2000 years old and, believe it or not, it still works! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to emphasize the fact that something does not happen or is not true
dictionaryExamples: "I never cry." "Not even when you hurt yourself really badly?"
Nobody spoke, not even the children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We tried to fish, but didn't catch a thing, not even a shoe! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say "no" or "not" strongly
dictionaryExamples: "Was he a nuisance?" "No, not at all."
I'm not at all happy about it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I sen[s]ed that invisible hand was touching my shoulder, but it didn't scare me, not at all. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to say that more than one thing is true
dictionaryExamples: Not only was the hotel expensive, it was dirty too.
You have let down not only yourself, but the entire team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this show, not only can we see [the] latest fashions, sportswear, make-up and hairstyles, but we can [also] enter for free. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to be much less good/bad/exciting, etc. than something else
dictionaryExamples: Her new book's not half as good as the last one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Probably they wouldn't be half as famous as they are without press photographers, journalist[s], etc. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to emphasize the importance of something that you are adding to a list
dictionaryExamples: The resort has great hotels and restaurants, not to mention some of the best skiing in the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She got a kitten, she hated cats[,] not to mention the fact that she was allergic to them. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: almost but not completely
dictionaryExamples: I'm not quite sure if I understand this.
The colors almost match but not quite.
He didn't get quite enough votes to win.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The student cafe has a welcoming atmosphere and most people said it was nice to sit and to drink coffee [there]. [T]he only problem is that there are not quite enough tables and chairs for everyone at busy times. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: used to emphasize that there is nothing of what you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: Not one person came to hear him talk.
"You haven't heard from Nick, have you?" "Not a word."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, I can only see buildings and roads. Not one single tree to refresh yourself from the hot and tropical sun at midday. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to emphasize that something is not true or will not happen, or to say "no"
dictionaryExamples: "She's not exactly poor, is she?" "Certainly not."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's nice, but do you think that money is all that matters? Definitely not! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian

sense.def: especially
dictionaryExamples: The whole trip was fascinating, not least because of the people I met.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are all human beings but we are all different, not least because of a different cultural background. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not at all
dictionaryExamples: I don't mind staying at home, not in the least.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Educating two children was not so easy a task, not in the least! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Farsi

sense.def: used to emphasize a quality
dictionaryExamples: The senator was nothing if not honest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I might be a bit bias[ed] but really, he is nothing if not extr[a]ordinary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to not have any sleep
dictionaryExamples: I was so excited last night - I didn't sleep a wink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, due to the fact that I hadn't slept a wink the previous night, I began to fall asleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: important or interesting
dictionaryExamples: With one notable exception, everyone replied to my letter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A notable exception is the advertising of so-called "slow-food" restaurants, which promote [a] healthy lifestyle. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: especially or most importantly
dictionaryExamples: They have begun attracting investors, most notably big Japanese financial houses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I have already indicated, the content (what they teach you) [is] very good, notably the training of speaking skills and a number of special courses, for example: How to Negotiate. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a short letter
dictionaryExamples: He left a note to say he would be home late.
Did you get my note?
There's a note pinned to the door saying when the store will open again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Rie Thank you for your note to me! Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: information that is written down to help you study, or to help you remember something you are going to write about
dictionaryExamples: The journalist took notes throughout the interview.
I studied European literature, and I still have all my notes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to bring with you a pencil, some chalk and a big notebook to take some notes and to draw in. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a short explanation or an extra piece of information that is given at the bottom of a page or at the back of a book
dictionaryExamples: See note 3, page 37.

sense.def: to write down information about something
dictionaryExamples: Let me make a note of your phone number.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After talking to other members, I have made a note of the main problems they considered the most urgent to be solved. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If two people compare notes, they tell each other what they think about something that they have both done.
dictionaryExamples: We compared notes about our experiences in China.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, regular meetings between parents and school teachers [...] help both parties to compare notes, acting in the best interest[s] of the children. International English Language Testing System; C1; Yapese

sense.def: to notice or pay careful attention to something
dictionaryExamples: Please note that we will be closed on Saturday.
Make sure you take note of what she says.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thank you for taking note of my view. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a particular feeling or mood
dictionaryExamples: a sad/serious/positive note
His speech had just the right note of sympathy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On a more practical note: I found the information pack I received beforehand insufficient. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: a single musical sound or the symbol that represents it
dictionaryExamples: Her soprano voice intoned the low, first notes of the song.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was as if an external force was stopping him from playing the notes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone or something famous or important
dictionaryExamples: There was nothing of note in the report.
Am ancient fortress is the only monument of note in the town.

sense.def: to notice something
dictionaryExamples: They noted the consumers' growing demand for quicker service.
Please note (that) we will be closed on Saturday.
Note how easy it is to release the catch quickly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please note that I am available for an interview. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: note down sth or note sth down

sense.def: to write something so that you do not forget it
dictionaryExamples: I noted down their web address.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were [a] couple of things I noted down during the show. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a book with empty pages that you can write in
dictionaryExamples: She was writing things down in a little notebook.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to bring our pencils, rulers, notebooks and books with us. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: not anything
dictionaryExamples: I've had nothing to eat all day.
There's nothing left.
Nothing I could say would cheer her up.
I have nothing new to tell you.
There's nothing else  we can do to help.
There's nothing much  to do in our village.
She did nothing but criticize.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This Sunday afternoon I have nothing to do. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: not something important or of value
dictionaryExamples: He's a dangerous person - human life means nothing to him.
She kept crying about nothing.
A thousand dollars is nothing to a woman of her wealth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't [worry], it's nothing serious. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: no other thing than
dictionaryExamples: She did nothing but criticize.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can read books in the open air while nothing but sea surrounds you. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

blocks.phrase: have nothing to do with sb/sth

sense.def: to have no connection or influence with someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He made his own decision - I had nothing to do with it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, I tried to explain [to] him that I had nothing to do with the vanishing of the cake but he didn't trust me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: be/have nothing to do with sb

sense.def: If something is or has nothing to do with you, you have no good reason to know about it or be involved with it.
dictionaryExamples: I wish he wouldn't offer advice on my marriage - it's nothing to do with him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The party was horrible: the guests were all talking about things that had nothing to do with me. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: without a successful result
dictionaryExamples: I've come all this way for nothing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortun[a]tely, I waited for nothing. The TV repair man didn't come! First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to be willing to do anything in order to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: He will stop at nothing to get what he wants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They stopped at nothing to get the higher scores, to make themselves noticed, even if that meant telling some lies to a teacher about a schoolmate. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to emphasize that something is not true
dictionaryExamples: He said that he was a legitimate businessman - in fact, he was nothing of the sort.
It was supposed to be a gourmet meal, but it was nothing of the kind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let me reassure you, nothing of the sort is happening at the moment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: used to emphasize a quality
dictionaryExamples: The senator was nothing if not honest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I might be a bit bias[ed] but really, he is nothing if not extr[a]ordinary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: used to emphasize other problems you have not talked about
dictionaryExamples: Most wild otters have disappeared from populated areas, to say nothing of wilderness areas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed would not it be an oversimplification to make one's judgement of the country's national character on the grounds of the amount and the quality of food people eat, to say nothing of the fact that this judgement is usually highly subjective? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to see something and be aware of it
dictionaryExamples: I noticed a crack in the ceiling.
Mary waved at the man but he didn't seem to notice.
He noticed (that) the woman was staring at him.
Did you notice how she did that?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly I noticed that I had lost the chain which Luke had bought me for my birthday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a sign giving information about something
dictionaryExamples: There was a large notice on the wall saying "No Parking."
I saw a notice in the paper announcing their marriage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nick - I've seen the notice about [the] concert. Key English Test; A2; Slovene

sense.def: a warning that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: The next time you visit, can you give me more notice?
The building is closed until further notice.
The emergency services are ready to spring into action at a moment's notice.
I'm sorry for the short notice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I apologize for the short notice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: attention
dictionaryExamples: I didn't take any notice of  his advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't take notice of it and deleted it again. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: only a short time before something happens
dictionaryExamples: I had to give a speech on very short notice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If required, I could additionally find time on week nights, however due to my professional duties I may have to cancel on short notice. International English Language Testing System; C2; German

sense.def: an official statement saying you are leaving your job or telling you your job has ended
dictionaryExamples: I'm giving my notice on Friday.
I got a 30-day notice yesterday at work.

sense.def: easy to see or be aware of
dictionaryExamples: There was a noticeable difference in his behavior after the injury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What was noticeable all over Warsaw were the overfilled garbage cans and litter in the streets that nobody cleaned up. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: in a way that is noticeable
dictionaryExamples: He was noticeably reluctant to meet her.
The new results were noticeably better than the last ones.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teachers' salaries are noticeably the largest part in the charts. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: to officially tell someone about something
dictionaryExamples: You should notify the police if you are involved in a traffic accident.
She was notified that her trial date had been postponed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must notify the director if you are not going to sleep in your room. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: an idea or belief
dictionaryExamples: The notion of sharing is unknown to most two-year-olds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, in ancient Greece, although the notion of the republic and democracy were invented and quite successfully developed there, not being a noble citizen could be cruelly disappointing and painful. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: famous for something bad
dictionaryExamples: a notorious criminal
She was notorious for her bad temper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from this, Bristol is notorious for its poor social policy for the people who are [o]n the poverty line. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: despite
dictionaryExamples: Injuries notwithstanding, he won the semi-final match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Notwithstanding this zealous kind of complaint, it would appear to me that they had great fun during the third day when after the English lesson they went to the swimming pool. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a word that refers to a person, place, thing, event, substance or quality
dictionaryExamples: 'Doctor', 'tree', 'party', 'coal' and 'beauty' are all nouns.

sense.def: a book that tells a story about imaginary people and events
dictionaryExamples: historical/romantic novels
Have you read any of Jane Austen's novels?
His latest novel is selling really well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I was sat on the bench under a tree in that wonderful garden and I was reading an interesting novel by Jane Austen, when a charming [young] boy [came] near to me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a person who writes novels
dictionaryExamples: His father was a novelist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher has told me that you are a British novelist who writes crime stories, and you have come to live in our area. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the quality of being new or unusual
dictionaryExamples: The fashion industry relies on novelty, and photographers are always looking for new faces.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Olivia's story takes place in a romantic atmosphere, which may allow the reader to look upon the colonial period as a dream; it sounds like a legend, a fairy tale, which fulfills an important purpose of novels: the appeal of novelty. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: an object, event, or experience that is new or unusual
dictionaryExamples: Tourists are still a novelty on this remote island.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our city needed a novelty like this and fortunately the dream came true! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the eleventh month of the year, after October and before December
dictionaryExamples: 5(th) of November/November 5(th)
Guy Fawkes' Night is on the fifth of November.
The factory opened last November.
He's starting his new job in November.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have [an] exam on 22nd of November 2006. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: at the present time
dictionaryExamples: I'm used to it now.
She used to be a teacher, but now she works in publishing.
I thought you'd have finished by now.
You should have mentioned it before now.
That's all for now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am now vegetarian! Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: We're going home now.
Shall we eat now or later?
I don't want to wait until tomorrow, I want it now!
I can't do it right now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please, buy it right now. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a very short time ago
dictionaryExamples: When I came in just now, everyone was laughing.
Who was that woman who was speaking just now?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [was] watch[ing] a badminton competition just now. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used to show the length of time that something has been happening, from the time it began until the present
dictionaryExamples: I've lived in Cambridge for two years now.
She's been a vegetarian for ten years now.

sense.def: used to say that something will happen very soon
dictionaryExamples: We're expecting our second child any day now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The evil creatures who were bound to come out of the dark [w]ould see Carla any minute now. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If something happens now and then, it happens sometimes but not very often.
dictionaryExamples: I love chocolate, but I only eat it now and then.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you really love to have a snack now and then, try to eat fruit and vegetables, instead of sweets. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: sometimes, but not often
dictionaryExamples: We still get together for lunch every now and then.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Each day choose 10 new words and learn them by heart. In a week you will have learned 70 new words, and in a year 3640, a lot of words. Please, do not forget to repeat them every now and then. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: as a result of a new situation
dictionaryExamples: Now that I've got a car I can visit her more often.
You should help in the house more, now you're older.
She's enjoying the job now that she's got more responsibility.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I am in England for fu[r]ther studies, I would be very grateful to you if you will give me the oppo[r]tunity to join your club. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: at the present time, especially when compared to the past
dictionaryExamples: Everything seems more expensive nowadays.
Who remembers those movies nowadays?
Nowadays, I bake my own bread rather than buy it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, nowadays I hardly ever watch television, as time is something that I really don't have enough [of]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: not anywhere
dictionaryExamples: The room was very crowded - there was nowhere to sit.
These young people have nowhere else to go.
Nowhere does the article mention the names of the people involved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was looking for it nearly everywhere, but it was nowhere! Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a long way from places where people live
dictionaryExamples: His car broke down in the middle of nowhere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I really don't want to [get] lost in the middle of nowhere. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If someone or something appears out of nowhere, it appears suddenly or unexpectedly.
dictionaryExamples: The car came out of nowhere and we had to swerve to miss it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was lying all alone on the beach, then suddenly, out of nowhere, right behind me those strange creatures appeared. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If something gets you nowhere, it does not help you to succeed.
dictionaryExamples: Bad manners will get you nowhere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As this is a loophole in [the] law system, it's creating a conflict between house-owners and squatters and getting them nowhere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: relating to the energy that is released when the nucleus  of an atom is divided
dictionaryExamples: nuclear energy/power
a nuclear power plant
the nuclear industry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He said that he was a nuclear scientist and we had met before. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: relating to weapons that use nuclear power
dictionaryExamples: a nuclear war/attack
nuclear disarmament
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the car isn't the greatest danger to human life today, because I believe the greatest danger is the nuclear bomb. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a person, thing, or situation that annoys you or causes problems for you
dictionaryExamples: I've forgotten my umbrella - what a nuisance!
It's such a nuisance having to rewrite those letters.
I hate to be a nuisance, but could you help me?
Local residents claimed that the noise was causing a public nuisance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [T]here are usually so many cars in cities that it is a nuisance to use them when you have to drive a short distance. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a symbol or word used in a counting system or used to show the position or order of something
dictionaryExamples: Think of a number smaller than 100.
Do you know what number their house is?
That's item number three on the agenda.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I chose the black one with the numbers in orange. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a telephone number
dictionaryExamples: Do you know his phone number?
Do you have my cell number?
I gave him my number.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Call me befor[e], and tell me what you like to eat? [Here]'s my new number 07782472751. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: a group of numbers that represents something
dictionaryExamples: Please write your credit card number on this form.
What's our flight number?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can [take] bus number 87, 77 or 156 and after 10 min[ute]s get off next to the post office and library and walk 2 min[ute]s. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: an amount
dictionaryExamples: The number of people killed in road accidents fell last month.
A small number of children are educated at home.
A large number of people were contacted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are a well-mixed class with equal numbers of boys and girls, all about 20 years old. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: several
dictionaryExamples: There were a number of journalists at the meeting.
We've had quite a number of complaints about the program.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are a number of errors in your article. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to give something a number
dictionaryExamples: Each volume was numbered and indexed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bus to Finspang is numbered 410 and there is at least one bus departing for Finspang every hour. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If people or things number a particular amount, there are that many of them.
dictionaryExamples: Our company's sales force numbered over 5,000.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They marched against Barovia with armies that numbered hundreds of thousands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: many
dictionaryExamples: We have discussed these plans on numerous occasions.
Shops of this type, once rare, are now numerous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact that my country produces numerous talented skaters is also a factor that helps me enjoy skating. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: someone whose job is to care for sick and injured people
dictionaryExamples: He worked as a nurse in a psychiatric hospital.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to be a nurse. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: to care for a person or animal that is ill
dictionaryExamples: We nursed the injured sparrow back to health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, there are more and more old people who need to be looked after or nursed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a place where young children and babies are taken care of while their parents are at work
dictionaryExamples: Does Jake go to a nursery or a baby-sitter?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoy working with children because I was working  in a nursery. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the dry fruit of some trees which grows in a hard shell, and can often be eaten
dictionaryExamples: a Brazil/cashew nut
Sprinkle some roasted chopped nuts on top.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally I would like to inform you that one of our students has [an] allergy to all sorts of nuts. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the food that you eat and the way that it affects your health
dictionaryExamples: Good nutrition is essential for growing children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, good exercise combined with the right nutrition (low fat, vegetables etc.) [will] alter our lives and help us feel and appear more relaxed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: relating to the food that you eat and the way it affects your health
dictionaryExamples: These snacks have very little nutritional value.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today, individuals have less time to prepare homemade food with high nutritional value. International English Language Testing System; C1; Farsi

sense.def: Nutritious food contains substances that your body needs to stay healthy.
dictionaryExamples: a nutritious meal
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They seem to have discovered that salads and pasta can be as tasty and nutritious as red meat. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish
